Semi-truck driver here.

I'll start off by saying my driving instructor (for my car license when I was 18) was texting and driving with me in the passenger seat on a busy freeway, and I wasn't a fan.

Since then, I pretty much refuse to ride shotgun with anyone I don't know and some people I do know. After getting my CDL and traveling across the country I've found that there are too many people who think driving is easy, and their complacency becomes the problem. They look down at their phones, look straight ahead, look back at their phones... All because "hey, this is easy, I got this"

If you don't find driving to be, at the very least, a mildly arduous task you are absolutely not paying enough attention to what's going on around you.

As I sit parked in Los Angeles, ready to make my way to San Diego, I'm dreading getting on the lonely 15 - which isn't that lonely here. It's terrifying.

Not only can this help drivers, it can help pilots as well. It's known in the industry that pilots can suddenly find themselves being overloaded with tasks, and that situation has been blamed for quite a few crashes where the plane managed to get out from under the pilot. That's why the entire industry (private, commercial and military) uses the phrase "Aviate, Navigate, Communicate" to give priority to those tasks. Most important task is to keep the plane in the air. The next important task is to orient the plane through the sky. And the final task is to communicate with other pilots and Air Traffic Control. But even with that, pilots might not know they're task saturated. Having some piece of tech that can help them know when their reaching their limits would be great. It can be used in a simulator environment to help show the pilots what it feels like for task saturation and help them navigate out of it.

Not saying that podcasts or audiobooks are the solution-- they're just my solution. Would still be vaguely interested in participating in one of these studies, but I'm also the kind of person who will say "don't talk to me while I'm driving" beforehand or "shut up" in the moment without regards to politeness bc I have such a low threshold for being overwhelmed.
